bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Howard A. Kelly, August 14, 1940

div1.p: Hench seeks information about the original Camp Lazear photographs. He draws attention to the incorrect identification of the mosquito building in Kelly's book. He inquires about the source of the “Gentlemen, I salute you” legend, and tries to find the addresses for Blossom Reed, Mrs. Lazear, and Carroll's family.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Howard A. Kelly, August 14, 1940
div1.opener:
August 14, 1940
Dr. Howard A. Kelly
1418 Eutah Place
Baltimore, Maryland
My dear Doctor Kelly:
div1.p:
The President of Washington and Jefferson College is dedicating a
Lazear Memorial Building at Washington, Pennsylvania this October. In connection
therewith, he asked me a couple of years ago to give a talk on the conquest of
yellow fever. I have spent considerable time in correspondence and in actual visits
with certain of the survivors of the yellow fever work in Havana. I have visited
General Kean in Washington, Kissinger in Huntington, Indiana, and recently spent
ten days with Mr. John J. Moran in Havana. While there, I found that the Cuban
government had lost track of the true site of Camp Lazear, and had erroneously
marked another site much closer to Camp Columbia, which is now the site of the
Military City. On this false site, they have erected a small memorial fence and
sign and have already purchased the land in preparation for the erection of some
sort of a memorial, for which I understand already two hundred thousand dollars
have been raised. Having at hand the popular article by Agramonte, published
in the Scientific Monthly for December, 1915, in which he precisely located Camp
Lazear, I was able to find the old San Jose farm. Presenting my information thereafter
to the Secretary of Defense, under whose department the development of the falsely
located site belongs, I found considerable opposition on their part towards accepting
my data. But, to make a long story short, they have accepted it tentatively, but
have asked me to submit to the Cuban government a documentary statement with my proof.
The basis of their locating the false camp site was a small photograph of a shack
presumably one of Walter Reed's experimental buildings and immediately adjacent, a
small framboyant (poinciana) tree. This does not resemble in any way in the buildings
and trees as shown in the photograph of Camp Lazear as published in your book in 1900.
The Cuban government has asked me to submit to them copies of the American official
photographs of Camp Lazear. I should like your permission to send them copies of
the two in your book, I should particularly appreciate knowing the source of your
photographs. Did you receive them from Dr. Reed or from the army? I have not seen
those photographs elsewhere and the U.S. Army Medical Museum in Washington does not
have copies of those used in your book. Indeed, yours are much better than theirs.
They merely have photographic copies (not the originals) of the two pictures in the
Surgeon General's report for 1901. If you have the films of these two pictures, or
any other films or photographs pertaining to Camp Lazear or Walter Reed and the
yellow fever experiments, I would be most appreciative if you would let me have
copies, for which I would be most glad to pay, or lend me the film.

Incidentally, I believe that one of your photographs is wrongly
labeled. You have called it “The Infected Clothing Building” but if one compares
the shape with the drawings of Agramonte in the Scientific Monthly for December, 1915,
it is apparent that it is the Infected Mosquito Building. I understand that the
man standing by this building is supposed to be Carroll. Mr. Moran was inclined to
doubt this and I wondered if you could clarify this point.

Both Mr. Kissinger and Moran have written for me their own stories
which have never been published, and which I hope to publish in some medical historical
journal under their own name. Both have told me that the legend about Walter Reed
saluting them and saying, “Gentlemen, I salute you!” had no basis in fact. It is
a nice legend, but does not happen to be true. I asked Mr. Moran and General Kean
if they knew where this legend originated, but they did not. Moran first saw it in
your book and I would be most interested to know what the source of your information
was. Was this Major Reed's own recollection of the event, and did he tell it to you?

Have you any idea where Major Reed's daughter now lives? Also where
Mrs. Lazear lives? I have so far been unable to find their addresses. Do you
know whether there are any survivors of Dr. Carroll? My search through the Army
Medical Museum and the Surgeon General's offices failed to reveal the original
papers of Reed or any others of the Board, and I am most anxious to get in touch
with the families of these Board members.

I cannot tell you how I appreciate your great help in this matter.
It would not only help me in planning my report to the Cuban government, but will
be of great assistance in the preparation of my address to be given at the Lazear
Memorial dedication. I will probably publish something on the subject and would be
delighted to pay my sincere acknowledgement to you for your help.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
